citation.article-title: Sporomusa malonica sp. nov., a homoacetogenic bacterium growing by decarboxylation of malonate and succinate.

p.s: Description of Sporomusa malonica sp. nov.
Sporomusa malonica (ma.lo'ni.ca, M.L.n. acidum malonicum malonic acid, malonica M.L.fem.adj., referring to metabolization of malonic acid)
Sporulating, curved rods, 0.7 x 2.6-4.8 μm in size, Gram-negative.
Motile by laterally inserted flagella, occurring singly or in pairs.
Spores oval, 1.2 x 1.5 μm, subterminal, heat-resistant.
Crotonate and 3-hydroxybutyrate, as well as butanol fermented to acetate and butyrate.
Succinate and malonate degraded to propionate or acetate, respectively.
Malate and fumarate, as well as propanol and 1,2-propanediol fermented to acetate and propionate.
Citrate, pyruvate, lactate, fructose, methanol, ethanol, glutamate, acetoin, formate, H2/CO2, and methoxyl groups of trimethoxycinnamic acid metabolized to acetate.
No other organic acids, sugars, or alcohols metabolized.
Growth in freshwater and brackish water mineral salts medium with small amounts of yeast extract (0.05% w/v).
Sulfate, thiosulfate, sulfite, sulfur, or nitrate not reduced.
Indole not formed, gelatin or urea not hydrolyzed; no catalase activity.
Mesophilic; temperature range: 15 - 38°C, optimum around 30°C pH range: 6.0- 8.5, optimum at 7.3.
DNA base composition: 44.1±2 mol% G + C (thermal denaturation).
Habitat: anaerobic sediment of freshwater origin.
Type strain: WoG12, DSM 5090, deposited with the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen (DSM), Braunschweig.
